question_details.title: Will the ISW warmap show Kursk as having been completely retaken by Russia on March 31, 2025?
question_details.description: Reuters: [Russia says it is poised to drive Ukraine out of Kursk as Putin spurs on his generals](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-says-its-forces-will-soon-retake-all-kursk-ukrainian-troops-2025-03-13/)
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if, at the [ISW Interactive Map: Ukraine's Incursion into Kursk Oblast](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/83a2f24901c941d581c0c523ecd2619b) Ukraine is shown as not controlling any territory in Kursk, denoted by "Ukrainian Advances in Russia," when checked by Metaculus on or after March 31, 2025.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Kursk almost retaken, Putin's forces now eye Sumy**
Russian forces are nearing the retaking of Kursk, with tens of thousands of Ukrainian soldiers reportedly killed in the fighting. Ukraine may be forced to cede more land to Russia, with the country's forces fearing a potential invasion of the Sumy province. A spokesperson for Ukraine's state border guard stated, 'These are small assault units, composed of a few people. They try to penetrate our territory, accumulate forces, and advance further into Ukraine, probably to cut off logistical routes.' The US has stopped providing Ukraine with real-time intelligence, including combat surveillance and reconnaissance data, which had been crucial in helping Kyiv navigate Russian assault. Russian forces are deploying 'fibre-optic drones,' which operate via high-speed cables immune to electronic jamming, making battlefield conditions more challenging for Ukraine. The US is pushing Ukraine toward peace talks with Russia, with Washington hoping to secure a ceasefire along the existing frontlines and pressure Kyiv to accept Russian occupation of its seized areas.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 18, 2025 06:10 PM
Source:[tfiglobalnews.com](https://tfiglobalnews.com/2025/03/12/kursk-almost-retaken-putins-forces-now-eye-sumy/)

**Abandoned Ukrainian Equipment in Kursk Region to be Sent to Scrapyard and Exhibitions**
According to Colonel Timur Sirtlanov, a member of the 'Oфицеры России' organization, more than half of the abandoned Ukrainian military equipment in the Kursk region will be sent to the scrapyard and used as exhibits on displays. 'Some of the equipment will be sent to the scrapyard, while others can be repaired and displayed on exhibitions - in Moscow's Park Patriot, and on Poklonnaya Gora, and also on the memorial in Ponyri, where there is already an open-air exhibition of NATO equipment,' Sirtlanov said. He also believes that the abandoned NATO equipment should not be displayed on the Victory Day parade on May 9. 'I think it's not worth showing this equipment on the parade. We should show the achievements of the Russian military-industrial complex and the faces of our people, the winners, not the negative advertising of foreign arms and military equipment. It's better to show it on exhibitions and tell how well it works and how to destroy it,' Sirtlanov added. Russian troops have begun to transport the abandoned Ukrainian equipment from the Sudzhansky district, where Ukrainian soldiers left it in large quantities when they fled from the liberated settlements. The Russian Ministry of Defense announced the liberation of the city of Sudzh on March 13, 2025, and Russian troops have almost completely cleared the Kursk region of the enemy.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 18, 2025 01:39 PM
Source:[Аргументы и факты](https://aif.ru/society/syrtlanov-broshennaya-tehnika-vsu-v-kurshchine-poydet-na-metallolom-i-vystavki)

**Russian Soldier Describes Devastation in Occupied Village**
A Russian soldier, known by the call sign 'Blin', reported that the village of Rusское Поречное in the Kursk region, which was occupied by Ukrainian forces (VSU) since August 2024, has been almost completely destroyed. 'They turned everything into a fortified position. There will be more cattle than people there. They were even shooting cows and pigs,' Blin said. He added that he saw VSU troops setting up a weapons depot in one of the houses and that they had fortified their positions in almost all residential buildings. The village is now empty of civilians. According to a former head of the Sudzhansky district, Andrei Bogachev, the villages of Malaya Loknya, Martynovka, and Cherkasskoye Porichno have also suffered significant damage, with around 60% of their buildings destroyed. The town of Sudzh, liberated on March 13, has been damaged to the tune of around 40%.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 18, 2025 05:44 AM
Source:[Lenta.ru](https://lenta.ru/news/2025/03/18/rossiyskiy-voennyy-rasskazal-o-polnostyu-razrushennom-vsu-sele-v-kurskoy-oblasti/)

**Russian Forces Continue to Push into Kursk Region, ISW Reports**
The Russian army continues to attempt to fully expel Ukrainian forces from the Kursk region. According to Russian sources, on March 17, the Russian army allegedly captured Gogolevka and advanced south of the settlement. Analysts from the Institute for the Study of War (ISW) provided an update on the situation in Kursk over the past 24 hours. Apty Alaudinov, commander of the 'Akhmat' group, stated that the Russian army has made gains in an unspecified area of the Sumy region, aiming to create a buffer zone after Ukrainian forces are fully removed from Kursk. Footage with geolocation from March 16 and 17 shows Russian forces advancing in the areas of Kurylovka, Guvevo, and Gogolevka in Kursk, as well as in the area of Basyovka in Sumy. Andriy Demchenko, a representative of the Ukrainian State Border Guard Service, reported that small enemy reconnaissance groups are attempting to attack Ukrainian forces in the areas of Novenky and Zhuravka. ISW analysts noted the presence of Russian 177th Marine Battalion units in the Guvevo area. Additionally, analysts reported that on the night of March 17, drones attacked an oil refinery in the Astrakhan region. Andriy Kovalenko, head of the Center for Countering Disinformation, stated that one of Russia's fuel storage facilities was hit. The governor of Astrakhan Oblast, Igor Babushkin, confirmed a fire at the refinery. As previously reported by Dialog.UA, analysts from DeepState discussed the situation in the Zaporizhzhia region near Malysheve.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 18, 2025 05:21 AM
Source:[Диалог.UA](https://www.dialog.ua/war/311068_1742270986)

**Russian Forces Continue Ground Operation in Kursk Region, Make Progress in Toretsk**
On March 17, 2025, Russian forces continued their ground operation to push Ukrainian forces out of occupied positions in the Kursk region. The enemy claimed to have captured the village of Gogolevka, but ISW analysts found no confirmation. Meanwhile, Russian forces continued to attack, trying to advance into the Sumy region. In the Kharkiv region, Russian forces continued to launch attacks on the north, but made no progress. They also attacked near Kupiansk, but again made no gains. In the Donetsk region, Russian forces continued to launch attacks on the North, East, and South, but the front line remained unchanged. However, on the Toretsk direction, both Ukrainian and Russian forces made progress. Ukrainian forces advanced in Toretsk, while Russian forces advanced south of Leonidovka. Heavy street fighting continues in Toretsk, with Russian and Ukrainian positions often just a few houses apart. Russian forces also made progress in the direction of Velika Novoselka, advancing south of Privolnoe. In the Zaporizhzhia region, Russian forces continued to advance, capturing the center of Malyshevbaky. However, on the Kherson direction, the enemy is not conducting active offensive operations.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 18, 2025 12:56 AM
Source:[24 Канал](https://24tv.ua/ru/karty-isw-17-marta-2025-gde-prodvigajutsja-rossijane-imejut-li-uspeh-vsu-novosti-ukrainy-24-kanal_n2777993)

**Ukrainian Forces Withdraw from Kursk After Failed Operation**
The Ukrainian forces in Kursk have withdrawn from the region after a failed operation. The Russian army has retaken the territory, and the Ukrainian forces are now in a defensive position. The operation, which began on August 6, 2024, was meant to push the Russian forces back, but it ultimately failed. The Ukrainian forces were unable to hold their ground due to a combination of factors, including the lack of support from the US, the failure of their own military strategy, and the effective use of Russian drones to attack their supply lines. The US President, Donald Trump, had suspended military aid and intelligence sharing with Ukraine on March 3, 2025, which some experts believe may have contributed to the Ukrainian defeat. However, the NYT reports that the Ukrainian forces were not encircled and that their losses were relatively low. The Russian army has suffered significant losses, with an estimated 40,000 casualties, including 16,000 killed. The Ukrainian President, Volodymyr Zelensky, has acknowledged that the operation was a failure and that the Ukrainian forces are now in a defensive position. 'We couldn't allow expensive rockets to be fired at the wrong target,' said Andrii, a Ukrainian officer. 'It was a mix of organized and chaotic withdrawal,' said Boroda, the commander of the Ukrainian forces. 'Various factors influenced the withdrawal: fatigue, good or bad orders from individual commanders, communication breakdowns - or good coordination.' The situation in Kursk is now stable, and the Ukrainian forces are preparing to defend their remaining territory.
Original language: de
Publish date: March 17, 2025 05:16 PM
Source:[www.Bluewin.ch](https://www.bluewin.ch/de/news/international/hat-trump-die-ukraine-in-kursk-verraten-was-dafuer-spricht-und-was-dagegen-2608199.html)

**'Horror everywhere': In Kursk, evacuated Russians long for peace**
Russia has evacuated 371 civilians from the Kursk region, which was recently retaken from Ukraine. Many of the towns in the area have been left in ruins by the fighting. One evacuee from Martynovka reported that the Ukrainian soldiers treated them kindly, saying, 'The Ukrainian soldiers did not hurt us. They treated us kindly.' The evacuation comes after Ukraine launched a surprise incursion in August 2024, trapping Russian civilians in the area.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 17, 2025 03:59 PM
Source:[France 24](https://www.france24.com/en/video/20250317-horror-everywhere-in-kursk-evacuated-russians-long-for-peace)

**Russian Ministry of Defense Releases Video of Abandoned Ukrainian Positions in Kursk Region**
The Russian Ministry of Defense has released a video showing abandoned positions of the Ukrainian Armed Forces (VSU) in the Kursk region, including equipment and ammunition. The footage, published on March 17, 2025, in the Telegram channel of the defense ministry, shows the locations of Ukrainian units near the liberated settlements of Kosiça and Cherkaske Porichne. The video features burned-out enemy equipment, Western ammunition and weapons, including a Ukrainian-made hand grenade launcher designed by American blueprints, Czech grenade launchers and machine guns, a Swedish hand grenade launcher, a Singaporean grenade launcher, and a Javelin anti-tank missile system. Russian soldiers also showed new drones that the VSU had not had time to use. As explained by a Russian sniper with the call sign 'Luna', the VSU lost support from their drones when Russian forces pushed them out of the forest, making it easier to advance to the settlements. Earlier on March 17, the Ministry of Defense released a video showing the 'Rubicon' center's FPV drones striking VSU equipment and personnel in the Kursk border area. The footage suggests that Russian forces had eliminated clusters of personnel, tanks, vehicles, including an American high-mobility multipurpose wheeled vehicle (HMMWV) and a quad bike. According to IA Regnum, on March 14, the 'Rubicon' center's FPV drones struck VSU columns leaving the Kursk border area. On the same day, it was reported that over the past week, Russian forces had liberated 28 settlements in the Kursk region, including Sudja, Viktorovka, Nikolaevka, Staraya Sorochina, Lebedevka, Kosiça, Mala Loknya, Cherkaske Porichne, Agro, Bogdanovka, Bondarevka, Dmitriykov, Zazulevka, Ivashkovsky, Kubatkin, Kolmakov, Martynovka, Mikhailovka, Pravda, Yuzhny, Kazachya Loknya, Pervy Knyazhiy, Vtoroy Knyazhiy, Zamostye, Mirovny, Podol, Melovoy, Goncharovka.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 17, 2025 10:37 AM
Source:[Новости России, СНГ и мира - ИА REGNUM](https://regnum.ru/news/3953807)

**Chaos and Attempts to Flee: Situation in Kursk Region on March 17**
The liberation of the Kursk region is ongoing, with Russian forces pushing out the remaining Ukrainian troops, according to NEWS.RU. As of the morning of March 17, intense battles are taking place near the Sudoga-Yunakivka road, where abandoned foreign equipment remains. Russian forces have already cleared several Ukrainian positions and are securing objects. In the Gogolevka area, Ukrainian troops have been largely pushed out, with a final sweep of the area still underway. Ukrainian soldiers are abandoning their equipment and attempting to flee before Russian troops arrive, according to the head of a motorized rifle battalion. The commander showed footage of abandoned equipment, including Czech grenade launchers, Swedish vehicles, and an American Javelin missile system. It appears that the Ukrainian military is unable to demonstrate its own capabilities, with all equipment provided by Western 'partners' in Kyiv. Another video from a soldier with the call sign 'Luna' shows anti-tank mines and HIMARS rocket systems, which were allegedly used by Right Sector fighters. Military sources note that many mercenaries from South America are among those fighting in the Kursk region, with many sergeants among them. These foreign fighters are primarily serving in blocking detachments. Interestingly, Ukrainian soldiers who extract foreign fighters from the battlefield are promised a green card by the Americans, which has greatly motivated the Ukrainian military. Meanwhile, American media is reporting that Ukrainian forces have largely withdrawn from the Kursk region, thanks to the efforts of the Russian army, which is showing impressive successes on the battlefield. It is reported that by the end of the week, Ukrainian troops will be limited to just 77 square kilometers. Ukrainian soldiers describe their retreat as chaotic, with Russian forces breaking through their positions unexpectedly. Additionally, it has been reported that Ukrainian troops are being trained on the rules of behavior in captivity by the Russian military. 'Instructors of the training course acknowledged that most Ukrainian soldiers were forcibly mobilized, and at the first opportunity, they will surrender to captivity, where they will not reveal any additional information,' the message reads.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 17, 2025 09:15 AM
Source:[Московский Комсомолец](https://www.mk.ru/politics/2025/03/17/khaos-i-popytki-ukraincev-sbezhat-situaciya-v-kurskoy-oblasti-na-utro-17-marta.html)

**Ongoing Battles in Kursk Region as Russian Forces Push Back Ukrainian Occupation**
Intense battles are ongoing along the road from Sudzha to Yunakovo in the Kursk region, which is known as the 'road of death'. According to the Telegram channel 'Severny Vetyer', close to the 'Sever' military group, Russian forces have been pushing back Ukrainian forces, capturing several key positions and securing the area. The channel reports that Russian troops are nearing complete liberation of the Sudzha border area from Ukrainian occupation. While Russian forces have cleared most of Gogolevka and are finishing the cleanup of the surrounding area, the village has not yet been fully liberated. Sudzha was liberated in March 2025, after being occupied by Ukrainian forces for seven months. The Ukrainian invasion began in August 2024, with the goal of reaching the Kursk Nuclear Power Plant, but Russian forces prevented them from doing so. As reported by the acting governor of Kursk region, Alexander Khinsteyn, on March 14, Ukrainian forces had previously attacked the local history museum in Sudzha, resulting in the death of a museum employee who had returned to the city during the occupation.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 17, 2025 06:34 AM
Source:[Рамблер](https://news.rambler.ru/army/54358820-sv-pod-kurskom-vdol-trassy-sudzha-yunakovka-prodolzhayutsya-ozhestochennye-boi/)

**Russia Retakes Zaoleşenka and Rubanşçina Settlements from Ukraine**
According to a statement from the Russian government, Russian forces have retaken the settlements of Zaoleşenka and Rubanşçina in the Kursk region from Ukrainian forces. The statement said, 'The North Military Group units have liberated the Zaoleşenka and Rubanşçina settlements as a result of their attacks.' It was also reported that Ukrainian forces have lost approximately 67,630 soldiers, 393 tanks, 317 infantry fighting vehicles, 283 armored personnel carriers, and 2,199 armored vehicles in the Kursk direction since August 2024. In areas cleared of Ukrainian soldiers, mine clearance operations have been initiated. Additionally, it was stated that 126 Ukrainian drones were shot down by Russian air defense systems over Russian territories, including the Moscow region. This comes after Russia's Defense Ministry announced on March 14 that Russian forces had retaken 29 settlements in the Kursk region over the past week. US President Donald Trump had previously called on Russian President Vladimir Putin to spare the lives of Ukrainian soldiers trapped in the Kursk region. Putin responded by saying, 'Their lives will be guaranteed if they lay down their arms and surrender.' The conflict between the two countries' armies began after Ukrainian soldiers entered Russian territory in the Kursk region on August 6, 2024.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 15, 2025 12:26 PM
Source:[Star.com.tr](https://www.star.com.tr/dunya/rusya-zaolesenka-ve-rubanscina-yerlesim-birimlerini-geri-aldik-haber-1932162/)

**Russia Retakes Gonçarovka in Kursk Region, Captures 12 Ukrainian Soldiers**
The Russian Defense Ministry announced that the Russian army has retaken the Gonçarovka settlement in the Kursk region from Ukrainian forces. According to the statement, 'The Gonçarovka settlement in the region was liberated by the North Group of Forces.' The statement also reported that 12 Ukrainian soldiers were captured. The statement added that the Ukrainian army has lost approximately 67,410 soldiers, 392 tanks, 316 infantry fighting vehicles, 283 armored personnel carriers, and 2,198 armored vehicles in the Kursk direction since August 2024. Additionally, it was stated that 28 Ukrainian drones were shot down by air defense systems over Russian territories, including the Moscow region, at night. This comes after the Russian Defense Ministry announced yesterday that the city of Suca, the largest city under Ukrainian control in the Kursk region, was retaken. Russian President Vladimir Putin also visited a command center in the Kursk region on March 12, wearing a military uniform, and received information from the Chief of the General Staff, Valeriy Gerasimov, about the situation in the region. Clashes between the two armies began after Ukrainian soldiers entered Russian territory in the Kursk region on August 6, 2024.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 14, 2025 12:28 PM
Source:[Yeni Çağ Gazetesi](https://www.yenicaggazetesi.com.tr/rusya-kursk-bolgesindeki-goncarovkayi-geri-aldiukraynali-12-askeri-esir-alindi-895753h.htm)

**Russia Retakes Gonçarovka Settlement in Kursk Region**
The Russian Defense Ministry announced that the Russian army has retaken the settlement of Gonçarovka in the Kursk region of Russia, which was occupied by Ukrainian forces. According to the statement, 'The Gonçarovka settlement in the region was liberated by the North Military Group units.' The statement also reported that 12 Ukrainian soldiers were captured. It was also stated that the Ukrainian army has lost approximately 67,410 soldiers, 392 tanks, 316 infantry fighting vehicles, 283 armored personnel carriers, and 2,198 armored vehicles in the Kursk direction since August 2024. Russian President Vladimir Putin visited a command center in the Kursk region on March 12, wearing a military uniform, and received information from the Chief of the General Staff of the Russian Armed Forces, Valeriy Gerasimov, about the situation in the region. Clashes between the two countries' armies have continued since Ukrainian soldiers entered Russian territory in Kursk on August 6, 2024.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 14, 2025 12:17 PM
Source:[Yeni Şafak](https://www.yenisafak.com/dunya/rusya-ilerlemeye-devam-ediyor-goncarovka-bolgesinin-geri-alindigi-aciklandi-4684288)

**Russia says it retakes another village in drive to push Ukraine out of Kursk**
Russia has reportedly retaken another village in its drive to push Ukraine out of Kursk. According to the defence ministry, Russia has taken back 28 Kursk settlements in the past week and captured the Ukrainian village of Novenke. President Vladimir Putin has instructed his commanders to eject the last Ukrainian troops as soon as possible, saying they would have to 'surrender or die'. Russian military blogger Yuri Podolyaka said fighting was taking place in the Ukrainian settlements of Basivka and Zhuravka. Ukrainian border guard spokesman Andriy Demchenko said small Russian assault groups were still trying to cross the border and push towards Novenke and Zhuravka, and Ukraine was using all available weapons to repel them. Russia has been largely absent from Ukraine's Sumy region since April 2022, when they withdrew from the border province to refocus their forces on eastern Ukraine.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 14, 2025 12:15 PM
Source:[ThePrint](https://theprint.in/world/russia-says-it-retakes-another-village-in-drive-to-push-ukraine-out-of-kursk/2548241/)

**Russia Announces Retaking of Gonçarovka Settlement from Ukraine**
Russia announced that it has retaken the Gonçarovka settlement in the Kursk region from Ukraine. According to a statement from the Russian Ministry of Defense, 'The Gonçarovka settlement in the region has been liberated by the North Group of Forces.' The statement also reported that Ukraine has lost approximately 67,410 soldiers, 392 tanks, 316 infantry fighting vehicles, 283 armored personnel carriers, and 2,198 armored vehicles in the Kursk direction since August 2024. Additionally, it was stated that 28 Ukrainian drones were shot down by air defense systems over Russian territories, including the Moscow region. This comes after Russia announced the recapture of the city of Suca, the largest city under Ukrainian control in the Kursk region, yesterday. Russian President Vladimir Putin visited a command center in the Kursk region on March 12, wearing a military uniform, and received information from the Chief of the General Staff, Valeriy Gerasimov, about the situation in the region. Clashes between the two countries' armies began after Ukrainian soldiers entered Russian territory in the Kursk region on August 6, 2024.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 14, 2025 12:08 PM
Source:[Star.com.tr](https://www.star.com.tr/dunya/rusya-goncarovkayi-ukraynadan-geri-aldiklarini-bildirdi-haber-1931931/)

**Russia's retaking of Sudzha deals blow to Kiev's reputation, expert says**
The Russian Defense Ministry has announced that the Battlegroup North has retaken Sudzha in the Kursk Region. Military expert Andrey Marochko believes that this victory has severely damaged the reputation of Ukraine's armed forces, stating that it will take them a long time to recover from the 'colossal losses' of over 67,000 casualties. Marochko also suggested that Ukraine will have no leverage in future negotiations due to the impending liberation of the Kursk Region, saying 'Kiev will have no trump card in the form of the Kursk Region at negotiations [between Russia, the United States and Ukraine] because the region will be liberated soon.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: March 14, 2025 03:23 AM
Source:[TASS](https://tass.com/defense/1927967)

**Russia Retakes City, Expels Ukrainian Troops from Kursk**
Russia has retaken the city and expelled Ukrainian troops from Kursk. Russian President Vladimir Putin stated, 'We defeated the Ukrainians in the shortest possible time.' The occupied Russian territory is seen as a potential bargaining chip in negotiations with Russia, which has already taken 20% of Ukraine's territory. The US and Ukraine proposed a 30-day ceasefire, during which a more permanent peace agreement would be negotiated. A US delegation arrived in Moscow to present the proposal to the Russian government. In response to the US tariffs on steel and aluminum, Canada announced it will impose new tariffs on American products, including computers and sports equipment, starting today. The new Canadian tariff is also 25% and will apply to imports worth up to $20 billion.
Original language: pt
Publish date: March 13, 2025 12:38 PM
Source:[UOL  notícias](https://noticias.uol.com.br/internacional/ultimas-noticias/2025/03/13/russia-retoma-cidade-e-expulsa-tropas-ucranianas-em-kursk.htm)

**Putin Visits Kursk Oblast, Orders Retake of Occupied Areas**
Russian President Putin visited Kursk Oblast on March 12, where he was briefed by Defense Minister Gerasimov that over 86% of the region had been retaken from Ukrainian forces. Putin instructed to retake all occupied areas as soon as possible, stating, 'The immediate task is to defeat the enemy as quickly as possible and liberate the entire Kursk Oblast.' This was Putin's first visit to Kursk Oblast since Ukrainian forces began their incursion in August 2024. Meanwhile, Ukrainian General Surovikin posted on social media that fighting continued in the vicinity of Sujovka, stating, 'In a very difficult situation, my top priority is to protect the lives of Ukrainian soldiers. As a result, our troops are moving to more advantageous positions as needed, and some units are withdrawing from Kursk Oblast.' This implies that some Ukrainian forces may be withdrawing from the region, which could be a setback for Ukraine's future negotiations.
Original language: ja
Publish date: March 13, 2025 09:40 AM
Source:[NHKオンライン](https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20250313/k10014748911000.html)

**Russia Announces Final Phase of Military Operation in Kursk Region**
Russian President Vladimir Putin has announced that the operation to retake the Kursk region from Ukrainian forces is entering its final phase, according to Kremlin spokesperson Dmitri Peskov. Putin visited a command post in the region on Wednesday and was informed by high-ranking commanders that Russian forces are on the verge of liberating the territory from Ukrainian forces, as reported by TASS news agency. Putin emphasized the need to conclude the operation quickly and establish a secure zone in the region. Russian Defense Minister Valéry Guérassimov stated that Ukrainian forces in the Kursk region have been isolated and systematically destroyed. The large-scale Ukrainian offensive in the Kursk region began in August 2024, according to reports.
Original language: fr
Publish date: March 13, 2025 08:57 AM
Source:[Les nouvelles à travers la Chine et le monde](http://french.xinhuanet.com/20250313/b7b1561a73a44fbe83b8d213fd31ae7c/c.html)

**Kremlin: Kursk Region Almost Fully Retaken from Ukrainian Forces**
According to Russian officials, the region of Kursk in southern Russia has been almost fully retaken from Ukrainian forces. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitri Peskow stated that the operation to expel Ukrainian troops has entered its final phase. Generalstabschef Waleri Gerassimow said that Ukrainian units in Kursk are surrounded and Kiev's plans have failed. The Ukrainian military has hinted at a partial withdrawal. Gerassimow reported that Russian forces have reclaimed over 1,100 square kilometers from Ukrainian troops, citing RIA and Interfax. Ukrainian forces had occupied at least 1,300 square kilometers in August. 'The plans of Kiev have failed,' Gerassimow said, 'the Ukrainian units in Kursk are surrounded.'
Original language: de
Publish date: March 13, 2025 05:52 AM
Source:[newsORF.at](https://orf.at/stories/3387494/)

**Russian Forces Report Successful Progress in Kursk Region**
Russian military officials have reported successful progress in the Kursk region, with Russian forces retaking control of areas previously held by Ukrainian forces. According to the Ministry of Defense, Russian forces have regained control of 32 settlements in the region since the Ukrainian invasion on August 6, 2024. In the past three days, Russian forces have retaken control of 19 settlements in the region, with 12 settlements retaken on March 11 and 5 more on March 12. As reported by the Ministry of Defense, 'The data we receive from our military indicates that our forces are successfully advancing in the Kursk region, liberating areas that were under the control of militants, and the dynamics are good,' said a military official.
Original language: ru
Publish date: March 12, 2025 10:08 AM
Source:[Ведомости](https://www.vedomosti.ru/politics/news/2025/03/12/1097530-uspeshnom-prodvizhenii)

**Russia Announces Retaking of Lebedevka Village in Kursk Region**
The Russian Defense Ministry announced that they have retaken the Lebedevka village in the Kursk region from Ukraine. According to the ministry, the Russian army's operations in the region resulted in the liberation of the village. The statement also revealed that the Ukrainian army has suffered significant losses in the region, including approximately 66,000 soldiers, 387 tanks, 300 infantry fighting vehicles, 264 armored personnel carriers, and 2,163 armored vehicles since August 2024. Additionally, the ministry stated that 88 Ukrainian drones were shot down by Russian air defense systems over Russian territory. This is not the first time Russia has announced the recapture of villages in the Kursk region, as they previously stated that they had retaken 5 villages last month and 3 villages yesterday. The conflict between the two countries' armies began after Ukrainian forces entered Russian territory in the Kursk region on August 6, 2024.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 09, 2025 10:46 AM
Source:[www.gercekgundem.com](https://www.gercekgundem.com/dunya/rusya-kurskta-lebedevka-koyunu-geri-aldigini-duyurdu-523141)

**Russia Retakes Village in Kursk Region from Ukrainian Forces**
The Russian Defense Ministry announced that Russian forces have retaken the village of Lebedevka in the Kursk region, which was occupied by Ukrainian forces in August 2024. According to the ministry, the Russian army's operations in the Kursk region resulted in the liberation of the village. The statement also mentioned that Ukrainian forces have suffered significant losses, including approximately 66,000 soldiers, 387 tanks, 300 infantry fighting vehicles, 264 armored personnel carriers, and 2,163 armored vehicles since August 2024. Additionally, the ministry stated that 88 Ukrainian drones were shot down by Russian air defense systems over Russian territory. This is the latest in a series of villages retaken by Russian forces, following the occupation of 5 villages in February and 3 villages in March. The conflict between Russian and Ukrainian forces began after Ukrainian troops entered the Kursk region on August 6, 2024.
Original language: tr
Publish date: March 09, 2025 10:36 AM
Source:[Anadolu Ajansı](https://www.aa.com.tr/tr/dunya/rusya-kursk-bolgesinde-lebedevka-koyunu-geri-aldik/3504433)

**Russia Retakes Sverdlikovo Settlement in Kursk Region**
The Russian Defense Ministry announced that the settlement of Sverdlikovo in the Kursk region, which was occupied by Ukrainian forces in August 2024, has been retaken. The ministry stated that the North Military Group's attacks resulted in the liberation of the Sverdlikovo settlement. According to the statement, Ukraine has lost approximately 61,310 soldiers, 369 tanks, 276 infantry fighting vehicles, 222 armored personnel carriers, and 1,901 armored vehicles in the Kursk direction since August 2024. This is in addition to the 63.2% of the territory that was previously announced to have been retaken on January 17. The conflict between the two countries' armies continues after Ukrainian forces entered the Kursk region on August 6, 2024.
Original language: tr
Publish date: February 17, 2025 03:11 PM
Source:[Haberler](https://www.haberler.com/guncel/rusya-kursk-taki-sverdlikovo-yu-geri-aldi-18385057-haberi/)

**Russia Retakes Nikolayevo-Daryino Settlement in Kursk Region**
The Russian Defense Ministry announced that they have retaken the settlement of Nikolayevo-Daryino in the Kursk region, which was occupied by Ukrainian forces in August 2024. According to the ministry, the Russian army has successfully liberated the settlement from Ukrainian forces. The ministry stated, 'North Military Group units, as a result of the attacks, liberated the Nikolayevo-Daryino settlement in the region.' The ministry also reported that Ukrainian forces have lost over 55,000 soldiers, 321 tanks, 238 infantry fighting vehicles, 184 armored personnel carriers, and 1,636 armored vehicles in the Kursk direction since August 2024. This is in addition to the 63.2% of the territory that the Russian Defense Ministry announced they had retaken on January 17, 2025. The conflict between the two countries' armies continues after Ukrainian forces entered the Kursk region on August 6, 2024.
Original language: tr
Publish date: January 27, 2025 11:06 AM
Source:[Haberler](https://www.haberler.com/guncel/rusya-kursk-bolgesi-nde-nikolayevo-daryino-yu-geri-aldi-18306144-haberi/)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, the dynamics of territorial control in conflict zones such as Eastern Ukraine involve back-and-forth exchanges, often heavily influenced by strategic importance, military capability, and external support. Looking at conflicts since the onset of the Russo-Ukrainian war in 2014, regions like Donetsk and Luhansk have seen fluctuating control. Given these precedents, there is an observable back-and-forth dynamic where territories are retaken and lost multiple times during protracted engagements. The likelihood of a swift and complete territorial recapture by either side can be relatively low, due to entrenched positions, resilient defenses, and ongoing international involvement. Historically, such regions have about a 40% chance of changing control completely within a short period, given major offensive operations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Russian Military Capability and Mobilization
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: After years of conflict, Russia has had the opportunity to refine its military strategies and capabilities, adapting to the specific challenges posed by Ukrainian forces. Their historically significant capacity to concentrate resources and adjust tactics could increase their success rate in territorial reclamation.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Ukrainian Defensive Strategy
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Ukraine has been resilient in defense due to international support and strategic depth, often employing asymmetrical warfare tactics that slow down and complicate Russian advances. Ukrainian defenses, especially near their border regions, are typically robust, leading to a lower probability of sudden territorial loss.

perspective_derived_factors.name: International Diplomatic Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Heightened international diplomatic pressure on Russia might deter overt military actions that completely alter the current territorial status quo, potentially limiting full-scale offensives.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Operational Success Claims
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Russia's recent claims of positive advancements can imply concrete momentum on the ground, possibly indicating their imminent strategic advantage in the specific region around Kursk.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Multiple news sources indicate that Russian forces have made significant progress in retaking the Kursk region, reporting liberation of many settlements and significant losses for Ukrainian forces. Russia claims to have cleared Ukrainian positions and evidence of abandoned weaponry and equipment further suggest Ukrainian withdrawal. The Russian Ministry of Defense announcements and reports of strategic gains support the notion of Russian control in most of Kursk by March 31.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Some reports indicate that fighting continues in areas such as Gogolevka and along strategic roads, with activities from both Russian and Ukrainian sides still evident. This ongoing conflict suggests that control might not be fully established by March 31.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, territorial changes in active conflict zones, like those in Eastern Europe during the Russia-Ukraine war, tend to be fluid but not necessarily rapid. The reclaiming of entire regions typically requires significant military advantage and preparation. The base rate for retaking entire regions in prolonged conflicts tends to be low due to the complexity and resistance involved. Examining past similar conflicts, a quick reclamation of a large territory is relatively rare—perhaps around 20%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Russian Military Operations
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Reports indicate Russia is actively focusing efforts on retaking Kursk, potentially bringing in reinforcements and strategic planning. This focused effort could lead to a temporary military advantage.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Defensive Capabilities of Ukraine
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Ukraine's military has shown resilience and effective defensive strategies, aided by western support, which could hinder Russia's ability to quickly retake the region.

perspective_derived_factors.name: International Support and Sanctions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Continued international support for Ukraine and economic sanctions on Russia might limit Russia's logistics and supplies, reducing its overall military efficacy.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Historical Precedent in Recent Conflicts
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: In several recent conflicts, even reported gains by one side can be unstable and subject to reversal. Lasting control often requires more time than stated immediate recapture intentions.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news reports consistently indicate substantial Russian military gains in the Kursk region, with multiple statements confirming that nearly the entire region has been retaken by Russian forces. Reports indicate that Russian forces have liberated numerous settlements, and Ukrainian troops are reportedly withdrawing from the region.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite Russian claims of victory, there is no complete independent verification of the total retaking of Kursk by Russia. However, the consistency and number of reports hinting at substantial Russian control align with Russia's official announcements.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, the recapture of territories in conflict zones can take a significant amount of time and effort, depending on the strength and strategy of the opposing forces. Given the nature of the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, the recapture of a strategic location like Kursk could take months or even longer. Additionally, major territorial shifts often require substantial military pressure and strategic advantage, which might not be fully achievable within a short timeframe such as a few weeks.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Military Build-up
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent reports indicate that Russia is significantly increasing its military presence and resources in the area, which suggests a heightened capability to retake and secure Kursk from Ukrainian control.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Ukrainian Defenses
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Kursk's proximity to the Ukrainian border allows Ukraine to potentially strengthen its positions and defense lines quickly, thereby making it more challenging for Russian forces to completely retake the territory in a short period.

perspective_derived_factors.name: International Pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: International diplomatic and economic pressure on Russia could affect its military operations and logistics, potentially slowing down or stalling its efforts to retake Kursk.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Winter Warfare Conditions
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: March weather conditions, particularly in Eastern Europe, can hinder the pace of military operations due to mud and difficult terrain, possibly affecting Russia’s ability to achieve rapid territorial gains.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Reports indicate that Russian forces are nearing complete retaking of Kursk, with significant Ukrainian withdrawals and loss of equipment. The news suggests that Russian forces have made substantial territorial gains and Ukrainian forces are in retreat, with videos and reports confirming significant headway by Russian military operations.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Some reports highlight ongoing battles and the final phase of the operation rather than full completion. Despite reports of progress, there's no definitive confirmation that Russian forces have fully expelled all Ukrainian forces from Kursk.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, territorial control during conflicts often shifts, but complete retake of a region is usually difficult and depends on multiple factors including military strength, tactics, and international support. In eastern Ukraine, where territorial exchanges have been frequent, complete retakes have occurred, but less commonly within a short timeframe (e.g., a few weeks). Thus, given the historical tendency for territorial shifts without complete retakes, I estimate a base rate of 20% for Russia to completely retake Kursk from Ukrainian forces by the given date.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Military Strength and Preparedness
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If Russia declares its readiness and is pushing forward actively, this implies a strong military push that could indeed retake territories. However, Ukraine has consistently shown resilience and defensive capabilities, potentially countering Russian advances. Considering both these aspects, a slight increase in probability is justified.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Geopolitical Pressure and Support
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Ukraine enjoys support from Western allies, providing it with military aid, which can bolster its defenses. This support helps Ukraine sustain control of contested regions, thus reducing Russia's likelihood of reclaiming territory fully.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Strategic Momentum
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent reports indicate a strategic position where both sides have been actively engaging. If Russia shows signs of advancing, this could signal momentum in their favor. Although, such momentum can be quickly hampered by Ukrainian defense, but still deserves acknowledgment.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Territorial Retaking Complexity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Given the complexity of completely retaking a well-defended region, especially in a short timeframe, the likelihood of Russia completely retaking Kursk against solid defenses is slimmer.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Numerous reports confirm that Russian forces have retaken several settlements and are making significant advancements in the Kursk region. High casualties on the Ukrainian side and the withdrawal of Ukrainian forces, combined with Russian statements about their nearly complete control over the region, strongly suggest that Russia is close to entirely retaking Kursk.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The final confirmation of Russian control remains pending as some Ukrainian forces have reportedly repositioned rather than being completely ousted, and ISW reports have not yet fully confirmed all Russian claims.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: The historical frequency of Russia claiming to retake territory and actually achieving it is mixed. The war in Ukraine has seen periods of rapid territorial changes, influenced by military strategy, international support, and geopolitical dynamics. Historically, given the unpredictable nature of the ongoing conflict and the complexity of accurately controlling areas, the probability could vary significantly. In similar contexts, such claims materialize successfully about 50% of the time based on past Russian military operations and territorial claims during the Ukraine conflict.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current military capacity
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent reports suggest that Russia has been amassing significant military resources near Kursk, which enhances their ability to retake and hold territory effectively, likely increasing the probability of success.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Ukrainian resistance
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Ukraine has shown resilient defense strategies and has received significant international military support, potentially reducing the likelihood of Russia entirely retaking Kursk by the specified date.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Weather conditions impact
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Weather conditions in late March in this region can impact military logistics and operations. Spring thaw (Rasputitsa) can hinder rapid advances of mechanized units, which may lower the probability of Russia fully retaking the area in their claimed timeline.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Geopolitical pressure
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: International diplomatic and economic pressure on Russia has occasionally led to shifts in their military operations. However, this pressure doesn't immediately translate into operational outcomes, so while it exists, its impact is limited on this outcome.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Multiple articles report that Russian forces are aggressively advancing and have retaken several settlements in the Kursk region. Reports of Ukrainian withdrawals and the severe degradation of Ukrainian operational capacity suggest Russia is likely to complete its territorial objectives soon.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite Russian advances, there is no definitive confirmation that Ukrainian forces are completely evacuated from all areas in the Kursk region. ISW and other analysts have noted ongoing battles and Ukrainian defensive efforts, implying that complete retaking by March 31 is not yet assured.

summary: After reviewing news articles related to the geopolitical situation in Kursk, the forecasting experts revised their probabilities regarding whether Russia will have fully retaken Kursk by March 31, 2025. Initially, probabilities varied among experts, with estimates ranging from 0% to 70%. Upon reevaluation, considering reports of Russian military advancements and Ukrainian withdrawals, many experts increased their probabilities. The revised probabilities range from 20% to 100%, with a general trend towards increased confidence in Russia's ability to retake Kursk. Key factors influencing these revisions include reported Russian territorial gains, Ukrainian tactical withdrawals, and the lack of definitive independent confirmation of complete Russian control.
